BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 11, 1921

BASKETBALL QUINT LOSES "LADY WINDEMERE'S FAN"
FIRST
TO
START
TO BE PRESENTED
SWARTHMORE.
Team Shows Promise—Poor Foul
Shooting Hurts—Owings Stars.
Freshmen Defeat Friends.

The Black and Blue tossers
went down to defeat in their
initial game at the Fifth Regiment
Armory Friday evening, being defeated by the Swarthmore five, 30
to 15. Early in the game the
visitors took the lead, which was
maintained throughout; nevertheless the showing made by the Hopkins quintet was much better than
was expected considering that the
material is practically green.
The first half started with Yarnall caging a goal from a distance,
then a foul by Benjamin, who
caged six fouls out of seven attempts in the entire game. Barrett' spectacular one hand shot
scored Hopkins' first point and
front then on the visitors massed
Point after point until at the end
of the first half the score stood
12 to 6 in their favor. It was
quite noticeable that some of the
men had. not forgotten their football tactics for the game was
marked by roughness, Bell Wood
and Cashell being Hopkins chief
offenders and Dieterle, Swarthmore, was forced to retire, having
four personal fouls.
In the second half Swarthmore
increased her lead gradually,
mainly by short and accurate
passes, while Hopkins passed
Poorly, many of their tosses going
wild.
The Quakers played a clever defensive game from start to finish,
but not until the second half were
they able to accomplish much on
the offensive. They thrilled the
Spectators with several long shots
and their clever passing.
- Hopkins' great difficulty seemed
to be their inability to shoot from
the foul mark, Owings, Cashell
and Bauernschmidt each taking
turns at free shots, but being able
between them to make only two
out of eight attempts. Owings
scored most of Hopkins' points,
making four field goals and one
foul, three of the field goals being
caged from difficult angles.
In the preliminary game Hopkins Freshmen defeated Friends'
School in a close and interesting
contest. The first half ended with
the score of 6 to 3 in favor of
Friends, but the Freshies came
back strong in the second half and
by an excellent display of team
work surpassed their opponents,
the final score being 14 to 11.
The cheering during the game
was very poor, due mainly to the
student-body being scattered about
the building. Burdell Cannon

VAN ORMAN ATTENDS INTERCOLLEGIATE MEETING

SWIMMING TEAM WINS AND
LOSES ON NORTHERN TRIP

Lack of Female Impersonators Force
Dramatic Club to Change Play.
Tentative Cast Selected.

Formation of Football Conferences Discussed—Dr. Abercrombie on
Soccer Rules Committee.

Downs Stevens by One Point—Loses
to Columbia in Well-Contested
Meet—Coady Stars.

After at great deal of work, involving the reading and careful
consideration of a great number
of plays, the Dramatic Club has
decided to produce "Lady Windemere's Fan" by Oscar Wilde as
its Major production of the year.
The play will be given on March
11 at the Lyric. It was originally
intended to give "Captain Jinks
of the Horse Marines," one of the
best known of the works of Clyde
Fitch and the play in which Ethel
Barrymore scored such a great
success a few seasons ago. It was
deemed advisable to change plays
simply because of the lack of Ethel
Barrymores at Hopkins. Twelve
men, many of whom had shown
unusual skill in portraying female
roles in the past, were tried out,
but none of these, it was thought
by Miss Walters, the coach, and
the committee which was selecting
the cast, could do justice to the
very exacting "leading lady's"
part. Everybody who could possibly have done the part was considered, but with no success. Then
since the play would have fallen
fiat without a splendid "Ethel
Barryniore" the change to the
Wilde play was made.
No one is the loser by the club's
inability to produce "Captain
Jinks." "Lady Windemere's Fan"
is one of the most famous of

The recent convention of athletic authorities held in Chicago
was productive of many decisions
of great interest to Hopkins. Dr.
Ray Van Orman, who was the
Hopkins representative at Chicago, comes back with word of
unusual results achieved by the

The Hopkins swimming team,
making a Northern trip, defeated
Stevens Institute at Hoboken on
Friday night, 27 to 26, but was
forced to bow to the Columbia
tankmen, 36 to 17.
At the New Jersey College each
squad turned in three firsts, while
in New York, Coady, who won the
220, was the only Black and Blue
man to finish ahead. This event
fell to Hopkins in both meets, as
Gould finished first against Stevens, with Coady second.
Stevens got away to a good
start when they took the relay, but
the Homewood clan hung on and
finally came out ahead when Hambleton and Gould finished first
and second, respectively, in the
plunge.
Fast time was made in the Columbia tank, and the score does
not indicate the closeness of the
competition. Hopkins again lost
the relay, partly because of a bad
turn made by one man. Columbia
won with the remarkably good
time of 1.49% seconds. "Davy"
Rowland was second in the 50 and
100, being nosed out by a hair's
breadth each time.
The 220 was a clean sweep'for
the Black and Blue. The fast pace
which Coady and Gould hit up was
too much for Steffens of Columbia, who was half the length of
the pool behind at the finish.
The trip may be considered a
complete success, for a victory
over Stevens and a doge match
with Columbia, one of the best
swimming squads in the East, is
an achievement to be proud of.

consensus of opinion
at Chicago that within a few years
the whole country will be partitioned off into separate athletic
conferences holding undisputed
sway over the leading colleges in
their districts. They will probably
be modeled after that which has
been so successfully conducting
athletic affairs for the big ten colleges of the Middle West.
For Hopkins this forecast has a
definite meaning. Either Hopkins
must get out and push the new
Middle States conference which
Dr. Van Orman is sponsoring or it
will be left out in the cold. The
University of Maryland has the
alternative of entering a southern
conference which is in process of
formation. But it is well known
that the College Parkers would
prefer to enter into an association

At a meeting of the Athletic
Board held last week Pierce
Brawner,'23, was elected Manager
of Football for next year.
OPEN HOUSE FOR HOPKINS AND
GOUCHER STUDENTS.

Saint Michaels and All Angels
Protestant Episcopal Church has
extended a hearty invitation to all
students of Johns Hopkins and
Goucher to a ,series of afternoon
teas which it will hold on Sunday
afternoons during January and
February from 4 until 6 o'clock.
These receptions will be held in
its parish house, St. Paul and
Twentieth streets. The Rector in
extending this invitation isequally
desirous of having members of all
denominations present on these occasions and hopes thereby to
create a closer relationship between the members of the two colleges. It is certainly hoped that
this offer of open house of the
church will be grasped by every
one. A pleasant time is assured.

MUSICAL CLUBS PLAY AT
ANNAPOLIS.

On Thursday night, January 6,
the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs
gave a concert before a representative audience at the Circle Playhouse, Annapolis.
The Glee Club rendered several
good selections—"On the Road to
Mandalay," which was featured by
a solo by Mr. Coulter; "My Little
Bimbo" and "The Lamp in the
West."
The Mandolin Club also performed. "Hiawatha's Melody of
Love," "Barcarolle" and "Hold
Me" were among the selections
rendered.
Messrs. Hambleton and Coulter
were up to their usual standard
•in playing Hawaiian music and
were accorded a rousing reception.
The Club as a whole was not at
its best, but it is hoped that by
dint of hard practice it will keep _
up the good standard set by the
clubs of past years.
It was announced that all rehearsals are called off until after
the exams.

TRYOUTS FOR iNTERCOLLEGIATE ORATORICAL
CONTEST
Meeting at Chapel Hill—Seven Colleges Enter—Cash Prizes to
Be Given.

On Friday, January 21, tryouts
Will be held for a speaker to represent Hopkins at the Southern
Oratorical Contest, to be held at
Chapel Hill, North Carolina, in
March.
Last year Johns Hopkins joined
With six other universities to form
the Southern Oratorical League.
The other members of the league
are Vanderbilt, Tennessee, Alabama, Virginia, North Carolina
and Kentucky. A contest is held
each year at one of the competing
colleges, this year at North Carolina. Speeches of not over 20 minutes are made dealing with political, social or economic subjects of
current interest.
The rules of the contest are few,

MAKERS

OF

speakers must be undergraduate
students. Prizes are awarded,
last year there being cash prizes
of $25, $15 and $10. The Southern Oratorical Contest is an important event. Johns Hopkins
must send the best speaker it has.
Tryouts, consisting of a very brief
speech from each candidate will
be held in Room 112, Gilman Hall,
Friday, January 21, at 12.30
o'clock.

At the organization meeting of
the track team over 50 men signified their intention of fighting for
regular places on the team. Included in this number were all
but two of last year's dependable
point winners, eight or ten men
of last year's second string who
are expected to develop greatly
this year, several men of unusually
bright prep school records and a
very large number of promising
novices.
The meeting, which was held
Thursday following the assembly,
was addressed by Assistant Coach
Lloyd, Captain Mulliken and Dr.
Van Orman. Both Dr. Lloyd and
Mulliken emphasized the necessity
of having a large and well trained
squad to face the "hardest schedule a Hopkins team has ever
bucked."
Dr. Van Orman, who is going to
coach the field men, told of the
advantages the rigorous training
holds for football men. His own
experience was that he got more
from his few weeks' training under
Jack Moakley, track coach at
Cornell, than from "Pop" Warner,
his old football mentor.
Despite the hard schedule the
quantity and quality of the candidates were highly pleasing to the
coaches and Captain Mulliken,
who before the meeting made no
secret of the fact that they were
distinctly worried. Since three indoor meets are close at hand,those
at Richmond, Washington and
Baltimore, will have come and
gone within a month, the candidates are in for some strenuous
work.
The field and locker house at
Homewood are this year arranged
more especially for track than
ever before. The board track is
again laid on Straus Field and
there is a locker room fitted up as
a gymnasium where the men can
go through their work with the
weights and other exercises in
doors.
.
The absence of "Joe" England
from the organization meeting was
keenly felt, but the announcement
that only an important case in
court could keep him away and
that he would again serve as track
coach brought forth rounds of applause.

The other important outcome of
*the Chicago meeting is the decision to hold a national college
Olympiad each year either to supplement or displace the national
intercollegiate championships. As
Hopkins will as usual be represented in the latter, this will probably add another meet to a track
schedule which is already bristling
with hard meets.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 11, 1921

The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of Llewellyn W.Lord,'21, from the office of
Editor-in-Chief.
H. Douglas Cotton,'22, has been
elected to succeed him, and C.
Warwick Perkins, Jr., '21, has
been made Managing Editor.
At the same meeting Eli Frank,
Jr., '22, was made Associate Editor and Robert K. Guggenheimer,
'23, and Harold H. McBurney,'24,
were elected to the staff as Junior
Editors.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 11, 1921
DRILLS FOR DELINQUENTS

BLUE SERGE SUITS
FOR YOUNG MEN, $33.50

Unexcused Absences to Count Heavily

in R. O. T. C.

The Professor of Military
Science and Tactics has announced that no member of the
R. 0. T. C. Units who has an unexcused absence on his record need
expect to be appointed to desirable
positions in the unit. In order,
therefore, that each student may
have a perfect attendance record
the Military Department has established drill periods on Monday,
Wednesday and Friday afternoons
when delinquents may make up
their work.
To put Johns Hopkins first on
the "distinguished list" this year
is the chief aim of the instructors
and students alike.. The R. 0. T.
C. leaders consider it absolutely
essential that there be a remarkably good record of attendance if
this highest position in the United
States is to bp won by the Hopkins
battalion, and the extra drill days
for absentees show a keen desire
on the part of the military office
to lose no opportunity that might
raise the University's rating as a
proficient military college.

President Goodnow has recently
received interesting letters from
two Johns Hopkins men studying
in Europe.
1 Rue de Fluerus, Paris, France,
November 6, 1920.
President Frank J. Goodnow,
Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md., U. S. A.
My Dear Dr. Goodnow—Permit
me to thank you for your letter of
presentation to the Director of the
Ecole Libre des Sciences Politiques.
I gave it to M. Caudel, the Secretaire General, who has charge of
foreign students. He spoke his
pleasure of receiving it, and was
most solicitous in helping me to
arrange my subjects.
My studies at the Ecole Libre
are in diplomatic history and international law. I am also studying Roman and French law at the
Paculte de Droit. Course in international law will be included in
my curriculum there during my
second and third year. I am now
planning to remain here three
years at least, attending the winter sessions in these two schools
and spending my summers in
Spain, Germany and England in
order to read the law of these
countries and get as thorough a
foundation as possible for work in
international law. Afterward I
hope to return to America to
study our law.
I trust that all is going well
at the University. It seems that
a diploma from Johns Hopkins
is quite a distinction over here.
Very respectfully yours,
MITCHELL B. CARROLL, A.B., 1920.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 11, 1921
WAR DEPARTMENT ASSIGNS
NEW OFFICER TO
HOPKINS
Lieutenant Williams to Assist Major
Garey—Has Seen Much Service
in Cavalry.

The War Department has honored Hopkins with an additional
regular army officer to assist the
Professor of Military.Science and
Tactics. First LieutenantAbraham
W. Williams is a graduate of St.
Johns College, class of 1916.
Alter leaving college he was with
the fourth provisional class at
Fort Leavenworth, from which
place he was sent to Texas to join
the Seventh United States Cavalry
at Fort Bliss.
After 19. months at El Paso
Lieutenant Williams was ordered
to Camp Meade and thence, in
1919, to Germany, taking over a
detachment of replacement troops
to Coblenz. On his return to the
States he saw further service with
the Fifth Cavalry in Texas, and
since April 20 has been on duty
in the. office of the Adjutant-General in Washington.
Lieutenant Williams is the son
of Mr. and Mrs. B. W. Williams
of Prince Frederick, Md., and a
cousin of the famous "Tiff" Williams of Hopkins lacrosse fame.
He has taken his examination for
promotion and hopes to receive
the rank of captain in the near
future. The assignment of this
officer to Johns Hopkins is further
to be noted for the fact that none
but infantry officers have heretofore been at the University. Lieutenant Williams is in the cavalry.

TO PLAY RUTGERS FRIDAY

Go to Annapolis on 15th—Navy Squad
One of Best in the Country—
Fast Events Looked For.

Freshman Contest With Severn Will
Make Doubleheader—Public
Dance Will Follow
Games.

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team will travel down to Annapolis on the 15th to meet the crack
Navy tankmen in what is expected
to be the hardest encounter on the
Black and Blue schedule.
The Navy squad includes some
of the brightest stars of high.
school ranks. Its bright star is
Kanakanui, a full-blooded Hawaiian, who is said to possess all
the aquatic ability of his race,
while Winkjer, a football man, is
also a member of the team. The
Navy entries will be as follows.
160-Yard Relay — Winkjer,
Emory, Kanakanui, Gallagher.
40-Yard Dash — Kanakanui,
Emory.
60-Yard Breast Stroke—Quinby,
Bearce.
60-Yard Back Stroke — McIntosh, Rowe.
Plunge—McCooly, 3IcCandless.
220-Yard Swim—Sinclair, Fish.
100-Yard Dash — Winkjer,
Emory.

Owing to the lack of co-operation from the Rutgers basket-ball
manager, the NEwS-LErrER is unable to publish the line-up or post
record of the Rutgers team, which
is to be met this Friday at the
Armory. The Varsity game will
be preceeded by a game between
Severn School and the Freshman
team.
From the records of former
years of the teams which are to
clash with the Black and Blue,
it is safe to predict two interesting
contests. The Varsity should by
Friday have had opportunity to
polish the rough edges which
marred its play last Friday, and
the Freshman basketeers bid fair
to continue the victorious march
they started last Friday.
The games will be followed by
an informal dance, the music for
which will be furnished by Tula's
Orchestra. These dances have
proved very enjoyable in the past,
and a large crowd is expected.

RIFLE

CLUB ELECTS
OFFICERS

Makes Plans for Coming Competition.
Large Enrollment Announced.

Charter members of the embryo
Hopkins Rifle Club held an organization meeting immediately
after the weekly assembly last
Thursday in Room 114, Civil EnStudentgineering Building.
Major Chisholm presided over the
meeting and explained that intercollegiate competition will open
on February 5, until which time
the rifle range will be open for
practice at practically all hours of
the day. Those not yet able to
shoot will be given special instruction at specific times. There
are at present about 60 members
of the club.
The election of officers resulted
President, W. C.
as follows:
Harden; vice-president, J. D. Garrett; secretary, E. H. Salter;
treasurer, R. Holmes • executive
officer, Capt. T. L. McMurray.
The official name of the organization, it was decided, will be the
Johns Hopkins University Rifle
Club. A meeting nest Thursday
after the assembly will be held to
adopt by-laws. A committee consisting of Captain McMurray,
Salter and Rich was appointed to
report upon initiation fees for all
non-charter members.
It would seem that the new Uni• versity organization should not be
hampered by financial difficulties.
The expenses will not be great,
as the Military Department will
loan all necessary equipment and
the club need, therefore, pay for
nothing but the upkeep of its
range.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 11, 1921

BASKETBALL QUINT LOSES "LADY WINDEMERE'S FAN"
FIRST
TO
START
TO BE PRESENTED
SWARTHMORE.
Team Shows Promise—Poor Foul
Shooting Hurts—Owings Stars.
Freshmen Defeat Friends.

The Black and Blue tossers
went down to defeat in their
initial game at the Fifth Regiment
Armory Friday evening, being defeated by the Swarthmore five, 30
to 15. Early in the game the
visitors took the lead, which was
maintained throughout; nevertheless the showing made by the Hopkins quintet was much better than
was expected considering that the
material is practically green.
The first half started with Yarnall caging a goal from a distance,
then a foul by Benjamin, who
caged six fouls out of seven attempts in the entire game. Barrett' spectacular one hand shot
scored Hopkins' first point and
front then on the visitors massed
Point after point until at the end
of the first half the score stood
12 to 6 in their favor. It was
quite noticeable that some of the
men had. not forgotten their football tactics for the game was
marked by roughness, Bell Wood
and Cashell being Hopkins chief
offenders and Dieterle, Swarthmore, was forced to retire, having
four personal fouls.
In the second half Swarthmore
increased her lead gradually,
mainly by short and accurate
passes, while Hopkins passed
Poorly, many of their tosses going
wild.
The Quakers played a clever defensive game from start to finish,
but not until the second half were
they able to accomplish much on
the offensive. They thrilled the
Spectators with several long shots
and their clever passing.
- Hopkins' great difficulty seemed
to be their inability to shoot from
the foul mark, Owings, Cashell
and Bauernschmidt each taking
turns at free shots, but being able
between them to make only two
out of eight attempts. Owings
scored most of Hopkins' points,
making four field goals and one
foul, three of the field goals being
caged from difficult angles.
In the preliminary game Hopkins Freshmen defeated Friends'
School in a close and interesting
contest. The first half ended with
the score of 6 to 3 in favor of
Friends, but the Freshies came
back strong in the second half and
by an excellent display of team
work surpassed their opponents,
the final score being 14 to 11.
The cheering during the game
was very poor, due mainly to the
student-body being scattered about
the building. Burdell Cannon

VAN ORMAN ATTENDS INTERCOLLEGIATE MEETING

SWIMMING TEAM WINS AND
LOSES ON NORTHERN TRIP

Lack of Female Impersonators Force
Dramatic Club to Change Play.
Tentative Cast Selected.

Formation of Football Conferences Discussed—Dr. Abercrombie on
Soccer Rules Committee.

Downs Stevens by One Point—Loses
to Columbia in Well-Contested
Meet—Coady Stars.

After at great deal of work, involving the reading and careful
consideration of a great number
of plays, the Dramatic Club has
decided to produce "Lady Windemere's Fan" by Oscar Wilde as
its Major production of the year.
The play will be given on March
11 at the Lyric. It was originally
intended to give "Captain Jinks
of the Horse Marines," one of the
best known of the works of Clyde
Fitch and the play in which Ethel
Barrymore scored such a great
success a few seasons ago. It was
deemed advisable to change plays
simply because of the lack of Ethel
Barrymores at Hopkins. Twelve
men, many of whom had shown
unusual skill in portraying female

The recent convention of athletic authorities held in Chicago
was productive of many decisions
of great interest to Hopkins. Dr.
Ray Van Orman, who was the

The Hopkins swimming team,
making a Northern trip, defeated
Stevens Institute at Hoboken on
Friday night, 27 to 26, but was
forced to bow to the Columbia
tankmen, 36 to 17.
At the New Jersey College each
squad turned in three firsts, while
in New York, Coady, who won the
220, was the only Black and Blue
man to finish ahead. This event
fell to Hopkins in both meets, as
Gould finished first against Stevens, with Coady second.
Stevens got away to a good
start when they took the relay, but
the Homewood clan hung on and
finally came out ahead when Hambleton and Gould finished first
and second, respectively, in the
plunge.
Fast time was made in the Columbia tank, and the score does
not indicate the closeness of the
competition. Hopkins again lost
the relay, partly because of a bad
turn made by one man. Columbia
won with the remarkably good
time of 1.49% seconds. "Davy"
Rowland was second in the 50 and
100, being nosed out by a hair's
breadth each time.
The 220 was a clean sweep'for
the Black and Blue. The fast pace
which Coady and Gould hit up was
too much for Steffens of Columbia, who was half the length of
the pool behind at the finish.
The trip may be considered a
complete success, for a victory
over Stevens and a doge match
with Columbia, one of the best
swimming squads in the East, is
an achievement to be proud of.

GOUCHER STUDENTS.

Saint Michaels and All Angels
Protestant Episcopal Church has
extended a hearty invitation to all
students of Johns Hopkins and
Goucher to a ,series of afternoon

MUSICAL CLUBS PLAY AT
ANNAPOLIS.

On Thursday night, January 6,
the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs
gave a concert before a representative audience at the Circle Playhouse, Annapolis.
The Glee Club rendered several
good selections—"On the Road to
Mandalay," which was featured by
a solo by Mr. Coulter; "My Little
Bimbo" and "The Lamp in the
West."
The Mandolin Club also performed. "Hiawatha's Melody of
Love," "Barcarolle" and "Hold
Me" were among the selections
rendered.
Messrs. Hambleton and Coulter
were up to their usual standard
•in playing Hawaiian music and
were accorded a rousing reception.
The Club as a whole was not at
its best, but it is hoped that by
dint of hard practice it will keep _
up the good standard set by the
clubs of past years.
It was announced that all rehearsals are called off until after
the exams.

Meeting at Chapel Hill—Seven Colleges Enter—Cash Prizes to
Be Given.

On Friday, January 21, tryouts
Will be held for a speaker to represent Hopkins at the Southern
Oratorical Contest, to be held at
Chapel Hill, North Carolina, in
March.
Last year Johns Hopkins joined
With six other universities to form
the Southern Oratorical League.
The other members of the league
are Vanderbilt, Tennessee, Alabama, Virginia, North Carolina
and Kentucky. A contest is held
each year at one of the competing
colleges, this year at North Carolina. Speeches of not over 20 minutes are made dealing with political, social or economic subjects of
current interest.
The rules of the contest are few,

speakers must be undergraduate
students. Prizes are awarded,
last year there being cash prizes
of $25, $15 and $10. The Southern Oratorical Contest is an important event. Johns Hopkins
must send the best speaker it has.
Tryouts, consisting of a very brief
speech from each candidate will
be held in Room 112, Gilman Hall,
Friday, January 21, at 12.30
o'clock.

At the organization meeting of
the track team over 50 men signified their intention of fighting for
regular places on the team. Included in this number were all
but two of last year's dependable
point winners, eight or ten men
of last year's second string who
are expected to develop greatly
this year, several men of unusually
bright prep school records and a
very large number of promising
novices.
The meeting, which was held
Thursday following the assembly,
was addressed by Assistant Coach
Lloyd, Captain Mulliken and Dr.
Van Orman. Both Dr. Lloyd and
Mulliken emphasized the necessity
of having a large and well trained
squad to face the "hardest schedule a Hopkins team has ever
bucked."
Dr. Van Orman, who is going to
coach the field men, told of the
advantages the rigorous training
holds for football men. His own
experience was that he got more
from his few weeks' training under
Jack Moakley, track coach at
Cornell, than from "Pop" Warner,
his old football mentor.
Despite the hard schedule the
quantity and quality of the candidates were highly pleasing to the
coaches and Captain Mulliken,
who before the meeting made no
secret of the fact that they were
distinctly worried. Since three indoor meets are close at hand,those
at Richmond, Washington and
Baltimore, will have come and
gone within a month, the candidates are in for some strenuous
work.
The field and locker house at
Homewood are this year arranged
more especially for track than
ever before. The board track is
again laid on Straus Field and
there is a locker room fitted up as
a gymnasium where the men can
go through their work with the
weights and other exercises in
doors.

that he would again serve as track

with hard meets.

DRILLS FOR DELINQUENTS

BLUE SERGE SUITS
FOR YOUNG MEN, $33.50

Unexcused Absences to Count Heavily

in R. O. T. C.

The Professor of Military
Science and Tactics has announced that no member of the
R. 0. T. C. Units who has an unexcused absence on his record need
expect to be appointed to desirable
positions in the unit. In order,
therefore, that each student may
have a perfect attendance record
the Military Department has established drill periods on Monday,
Wednesday and Friday afternoons
when delinquents may make up
their work.
To put Johns Hopkins first on
the "distinguished list" this year
is the chief aim of the instructors
and students alike.. The R. 0. T.
C. leaders consider it absolutely
essential that there be a remarkably good record of attendance if
this highest position in the United
States is to bp won by the Hopkins
battalion, and the extra drill days
for absentees show a keen desire
on the part of the military office
to lose no opportunity that might
raise the University's rating as a
proficient military college.

President Goodnow has recently
received interesting letters from
two Johns Hopkins men studying
in Europe.
1 Rue de Fluerus, Paris, France,
November 6, 1920.
President Frank J. Goodnow,
Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md., U. S. A.
My Dear Dr. Goodnow—Permit
me to thank you for your letter of
presentation to the Director of the
Ecole Libre des Sciences Politiques.
I gave it to M. Caudel, the Secretaire General, who has charge of
foreign students. He spoke his
pleasure of receiving it, and was
most solicitous in helping me to
arrange my subjects.
My studies at the Ecole Libre
are in diplomatic history and international law. I am also studying Roman and French law at the
Paculte de Droit. Course in international law will be included in
my curriculum there during my
second and third year. I am now
planning to remain here three
years at least, attending the winter sessions in these two schools
and spending my summers in
Spain, Germany and England in
order to read the law of these
countries and get as thorough a
foundation as possible for work in
international law. Afterward I
hope to return to America to
study our law.
I trust that all is going well
at the University. It seems that
a diploma from Johns Hopkins
is quite a distinction over here.
Very respectfully yours,
MITCHELL B. CARROLL, A.B., 1920.

Dear Sir---4 should like to urge
every member of the student
body—at least all those who have
any college spirit—not to lightly
disregard the notices recently sent
out by the Dormitory Committee.
Similar notices were sent out last
fall but apparently without much

signed not only for a certain definite sum but also for a definite

is impossible for the committee to

Every Hopkins man must realize
how important, how vital in fact,

It is
almost impossible to attract men

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 11, 1921
WAR DEPARTMENT ASSIGNS
NEW OFFICER TO
HOPKINS
Lieutenant Williams to Assist Major
Garey—Has Seen Much Service
in Cavalry.

The War Department has honored Hopkins with an additional
regular army officer to assist the
Professor of Military.Science and
Tactics. First LieutenantAbraham
W. Williams is a graduate of St.
Johns College, class of 1916.
Alter leaving college he was with
the fourth provisional class at
Fort Leavenworth, from which
place he was sent to Texas to join
the Seventh United States Cavalry
at Fort Bliss.
After 19. months at El Paso
Lieutenant Williams was ordered
to Camp Meade and thence, in
1919, to Germany, taking over a
detachment of replacement troops
to Coblenz. On his return to the
States he saw further service with
the Fifth Cavalry in Texas, and
since April 20 has been on duty
in the. office of the Adjutant-General in Washington.
Lieutenant Williams is the son
of Mr. and Mrs. B. W. Williams
of Prince Frederick, Md., and a
cousin of the famous "Tiff" Williams of Hopkins lacrosse fame.
He has taken his examination for
promotion and hopes to receive
the rank of captain in the near
future. The assignment of this
officer to Johns Hopkins is further
to be noted for the fact that none
but infantry officers have heretofore been at the University. Lieutenant Williams is in the cavalry.

TO PLAY RUTGERS FRIDAY

Go to Annapolis on 15th—Navy Squad
One of Best in the Country—
Fast Events Looked For.

Freshman Contest With Severn Will
Make Doubleheader—Public
Dance Will Follow
Games.

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team will travel down to Annapolis on the 15th to meet the crack
Navy tankmen in what is expected
to be the hardest encounter on the
Black and Blue schedule.
The Navy squad includes some
of the brightest stars of high.
school ranks. Its bright star is
Kanakanui, a full-blooded Hawaiian, who is said to possess all
the aquatic ability of his race,
while Winkjer, a football man, is
also a member of the team. The
Navy entries will be as follows.
160-Yard Relay — Winkjer,
Emory, Kanakanui, Gallagher.
40-Yard Dash — Kanakanui,
Emory.
60-Yard Breast Stroke—Quinby,
Bearce.
60-Yard Back Stroke — McIntosh, Rowe.
Plunge—McCooly, 3IcCandless.
220-Yard Swim—Sinclair, Fish.
100-Yard Dash — Winkjer,
Emory.

Owing to the lack of co-operation from the Rutgers basket-ball
manager, the NEwS-LErrER is unable to publish the line-up or post
record of the Rutgers team, which
is to be met this Friday at the
Armory. The Varsity game will
be preceeded by a game between
Severn School and the Freshman
team.
From the records of former
years of the teams which are to
clash with the Black and Blue,
it is safe to predict two interesting
contests. The Varsity should by
Friday have had opportunity to
polish the rough edges which
marred its play last Friday, and
the Freshman basketeers bid fair
to continue the victorious march
they started last Friday.
The games will be followed by
an informal dance, the music for
which will be furnished by Tula's
Orchestra. These dances have
proved very enjoyable in the past,
and a large crowd is expected.

RIFLE

CLUB ELECTS
OFFICERS

Makes Plans for Coming Competition.
Large Enrollment Announced.

Charter members of the embryo
Hopkins Rifle Club held an organization meeting immediately
after the weekly assembly last
Thursday in Room 114, Civil EnStudentgineering Building.
Major Chisholm presided over the
meeting and explained that intercollegiate competition will open
on February 5, until which time
the rifle range will be open for
practice at practically all hours of
the day. Those not yet able to
shoot will be given special instruction at specific times. There
are at present about 60 members
of the club.
The election of officers resulted
President, W. C.
as follows:
Harden; vice-president, J. D. Garrett; secretary, E. H. Salter;
treasurer, R. Holmes • executive
officer, Capt. T. L. McMurray.
The official name of the organization, it was decided, will be the
Johns Hopkins University Rifle
Club. A meeting nest Thursday
after the assembly will be held to
adopt by-laws. A committee consisting of Captain McMurray,
Salter and Rich was appointed to
report upon initiation fees for all
non-charter members.
It would seem that the new Uni• versity organization should not be
hampered by financial difficulties.
The expenses will not be great,
as the Military Department will
loan all necessary equipment and
the club need, therefore, pay for
nothing but the upkeep of its
range.
